newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentina to privatize tax collection - official.
newsitem.headline: Argentina to privatize tax collection - official.

text.p: Carlos Silvani, head of Argentina's DGI tax office and customs services, said Tuesday the government would privatize the collection of unpaid taxes for those owing less than $50,000.

According to Silvani, Argentines owe the tax authorities a total of about $7 billion, the equivalent of two months of government revenue. The partial privatization of the collection service would speed up the payments of the debts and make collection more efficient, he said.
"We want to expedite the payment of delayed payments," Silvani told journalists.

The fight against tax evasion, estimated by President Carlos Menem at $20 billion annually, has become an important element in the government's efforts to bridge a fiscal gap expected to reach $5 billion this year.
"It was the president's decision to get payment of unpaid taxes quickly. The president was very emphatic that the payments be accelerated," said Silvani.
The official did not give any details of how the service would be privatized.
Silvani, who said he was visited by Menem Tuesday at the tax office -- the first time in 40 years a president made such a visit -- said he was looking for ways to simplify tax collection.
